handDesc.p: Other palaeographic observations. Anusvāra is normally to the right of the character to which it belongs, but may be above it; it is possibly inside the i marker on the next character in l15 vaṁgipaṟu. Retroflex ṇa has a shape that I find unusual, with the left wing bent down to form a closed loop with the top of the body. Doubling of consonants is occasionally omitted after r, e.g. l8 suvarṇa, l19 sarva, pūrvataḥ. In go (end of l1), the left-hand marker is attached to the lower part of the body.

app.note: The reading is clear, but I find it slightly odd. Were it not corroborated by the identical locus in line 6 of the Dinakādu grant, I would emend to vijita. Beyond that grant, the closest parallel I can find is sva-bhuja-bala-vijitāri-saṁhates in the Pedda-Vegi plates of Jayasiṁha I.

The writing is badly worn here and it is not impossible that v is in fact present. I prefer to read/restore sva in preference to sa. This is confirmed by the identical locus in line 9 of the Dinakādu grant. Other related grants use sva-bhuja-bala-pratāpāvanata or simply pratāpāvanata in similar contexts, while the Varppoṁgu plates of Vijayāditya II read pratāpānurāgāvanata-samasta-sāmanta-cakkraḥ in an almost identical context.

ARIE reports the name of the village as Nemmalūru. The first character is indistinct in the estampage, but SR's go appears to be impossible from the vestiges (compare go in lines 1 and 15). What is visible in the estampage consists of a horizontal line with a downward hook at the left, which is likely an e marker; a curved stem attaching this stroke to the body on the right-hand edge of the character; and the upper left portion of the body, which resembles a quarter oval. The shape is most reminiscent of a partially preserved kha, but khā in line 14 is too damaged to serve for a comparison. Indications for this and against ne are the curly left end of the upper horizontal stroke (which would probably be less curly if it were an e) and by the curvature of the vertical stroke (where a straight vertical stem would be expected in n). These indications are not, however, decisive. I assume that the ARIE editor had a good look at the original plates and was therefore in a better position to judge. Moreover, there is a present-day village Nimmaluru at 16° 16′ 13.08″ N, 80° 59′ 48.12″ E, in Gudivada taluk of Krishna district (so probably in Gudrahāra Viṣaya), though not in West Godavari district, where the inscription is said to have been found. There is a stream (koḍu?) to the west of this village, but I find no names recognisable from the grant in its vicinity. For these considerations I prefer the reading nemmaḷūru, but khammaḷūru may also be correct, and other readings such as vemmaḷūru cannot be excluded.
SR prints this reading both in his edition and in his discussion, so it is probably not a typo. If an anusvāra is present, then it is inside the circle of i over gi.

Though the text is meaningful without this emendation, because of this compound's position in the sequence I believe this was the intent of the composer, so that the learnedness of each of the three generations is described with one adjective (rather than one for the grandfather, none for the father, and two for the donee).
Although no e is visible in the estampage, it seems likely that one was present here.

The latter half of this word is quite certainly boya. The first character is uncertain, but definitely not ṣe, which may be a typo in SR's edition. In addition to ce, it may be co, kha or khā. The second character does not appear to be ṇḍa, but that may have been intended if the first character is kha.

Being unable to interpret this word, I am uncertain of its reading. The subscript component of the first character is definitely ḻ. Its vowel marker rises very high above the body before bending down and would imply the vowel au. There is definitely no second stroke on the left, but the au of pautrikaṁ in line 28 may also be written with a single cursive stroke. Nonetheless, au being unlikely in a vernacular word, the intent was probably ā; the vowel marker in ṣā a little further on in this line rises almost as high. The second character is probably nda, but ṇḍa, nde and ndo are also possible. The third character's consonant component may be ḻ, but ṟ is more likely. There seems to be a small vowel marker attached to its body on the right, and there is plenty of space to its left, so I assume that there was a second vowel marker (together for o) here.

Though the first character is damaged, SR's reading can be ruled out on the basis of the estampage alone. Moreover, Boḻama is also the executor of the Zulakallu and Eḍeru of plates Vijayāditya I. This has also been pointed out by G. S. Gai (
301 1 ).
This last character is indistinct, but it does not plausibly look like śrī. Perhaps SR too saw a spiral here, and rendered it as śrī, neglecting to note that this is represented by a symbol.

div.head: Plates
div.p: Greetings. The dear grandson of His Majesty Maṅgi Yuvarāja, who was eager to adorn the lineage of the majestic Caḷukyas—who are of the Mānavya gotra which is praised by the entire world, who are sons of Hārīti, who attained kingship by the grace of Kauśikī’s boon, who are protected by the band of Mothers, who were deliberately appointed to kingship by Lord Mahāsena, to whom the realms of adversaries instantaneously submit at the mere sight of the superior Boar emblem they have acquired by the grace of the divine Nārāyaṇa, and whose bodies have been hallowed through washing in the purificatory ablutions avabhr̥tha of the Aśvamedha sacrifice—; the dear son of His Majesty King mahārāja Viṣṇuvardhana III, the shelter of all the world sarva-lokāśraya , who has fended offThis reading strikes me as strange; I would expect "conquered" here. See the apparatus to line 7. the entire circle of kings by the power of his own arm, and whose resplendent fame was heightened by gifts of gold weighed in many a balance against his body; namely His Majesty the supremely pious Supreme Lord parameśvara of Emperors mahārājādhirāja , the Sovereign bhaṭṭāraka Vijayāditya, shelter of the entire universe samasta-bhuvanāśraya , supreme devotee of Maheśvara, who was deliberately appointed as heir by his mother and father, who has the complete circle of peripheral rulers sāmanta bowed down through his own prowess, who possesses the bodily marks of a universal sovereign cakravartin and who is adorned by a host of irreproachable niravadya and noble virtues, commands all householders kuṭumbin —including foremost the territorial overseers rāṣṭrakūṭa —inhabiting the village Nemmaḷūru in Gudrahāra district viṣaya as follows:

Let it be known to you that on the occasion of an eclipse of the moon we have given, sanctified by a libation of water and with a remission of all taxes, a field to the extent sufficient for sowing eight khaṇḍikas of kodrava to the grandson of the caturvedin Mādhavaśarman, the son of Śivaśarman who was versed in the Vedas and the VedāṅgasAs per the received text, the qualification “versed in the Vedas and the Vedāṅgas” applies to the donee, but I believe it was intended to describe his father; see the apparatus to line 16. namely Mādhavaśarman, a student of two Vedas, a resident of Vaṁgipaṟu of the Bhāradvāja gotra who is endowed with his i.e. his father’s virtues.

To the east, ciṭṭeruguṭa maṭṭabu. To the south, the field of Cendaṟū-boya. To the west, a stream koḍu . To the north, pḻāndaṟobu. The field is located amid these four boundaries. To the west of the village. Let no-one pose an obstacle to his enjoyment of his rights over it. He who does so shall be conjoined with the five great sins. Vyāsa too has said:
Many kings have granted land, and many have preserved it as formerly granted. Whosoever at any time owns the land, the fruit reward accrued of granting it belongs to him at that time.
He who would seize land, whether given by himself or by another, shall be born as a worm in faeces for sixty thousand years.
The property of a Brahmin is terrible poison: it is not actual poison that is properly called poison. Poison kills just the one man, while seizing the property of a Brahmin destroys his progeny.
